hed: 21 Grilled Chickens That Make the Grade
dek: Just because it's basic doesn't mean it's boring.
promoDek: Just because it's basic doesn't mean it's boring.
promoHed: 21 Ways to Make Grilled Chicken Better
seoDescription: These grilled chicken recipes are perfect for barbecue and marinating.
socialTitle: Grilled Chickens That Make the Grade
socialDescription: Go beyond the bottled sauce with these grilled chicken riffs.

items.caption: Here's the whole deal on grilling whole chicken: spatchcocking is the answer. By butterflying the bird, you're exposing much of the skin to the grill grates, leading to even more crispy chicken skin.
How do you make grilled chicken special? You're looking at it. Adding tomato paste and soy sauce provide deep umami notes that keep the sauce from getting too out-of-control spicy.
Chicken and polenta are a pretty standard combination until Dijon comes into the picture. Rubbing the mustard into the chicken before grilling acts as a tenderizer and adds a note of sharpness.
Honeydew melon makes a heck of a salsa. Sweet and spicy, it's enough to add some zest into grilled chicken.
At least three hours before grilling, soak the chicken in the easy peanut-apricot marinade for at least three hours. Nutty, creamy, and even slightly sweet, it also makes a killer sauce.
Give grilled chicken tostadas the royal treatment: by putting on some coriander, you're giving the grilled chicken a luxurious makeover.

There's not much extra you can do to really riff on a grilled chicken wing, until you consider the sauce strategy. Can't decide between Buffalo sauce or lemon pepper? By making five different sauces, you cover all of your bases.
Grilling garlic and red scallions tames the alliums' bite and gives them a robust flavor.
Where's the tang coming from in this chicken? The breakfast bowl. Boasting a high acidity and creaminess, yogurt makes a pretty great marinade.
Put away the boneless and skinless chicken breasts and use chicken thighs for these flavorful and rich tacos.
The trick to making a moist brochette: use chicken thighs, not breasts. The darker meat has more fat content and richness that goes over well in this Moroccan wrap.
Tarragon + Pistachio=the most unexpected pesto ever. These chicken skewers would also make for a casual dinner party. Just serve with couscous and rice on the side.
Give your peaches some heat by adding chipotles in adobo. A little goes a long way in making this peach marinade a keeper.
Can't stand cumin? Get ready to have your expectations change. Cumin, smoked paprika, and other bold spices in the rub come together with a chunky salsa of tomatillos, chile, lime, and cilantro.
You read it right: grilled radishes. Buttery, sharp, and an excellent accompaniment to this Asian-style grilled chicken.
Pro tip for this lemon and parsley beauty: when turning the chicken, pick up the pieces by the drumstick.
Giving this grilled chicken's citrus marinade a swig of tequila brings on some extra heat.

The seductively high ratio of skin to meat is what makes wings taste so good, and grilling takes full advantage of that. This herb marinade is bright and summery, and light enough to let the skin get nice and crisp.
How to keep your chicken from going up in flames: cook it skin-side up. Top this grilled beauty with fresh oregano and tomatoes in chili-fennel oil.
Crisp on the outside, juicy interior. Sounds impossible until you try spatchcocking, the splitting and flattening chicken technique.
How to grill like you're in Turkey: start with chicken thighs marinated in thick yogurt, chile paste, and garlic and grill over charcoal.
